# Deep Dive: Sierpiński Triangle.


## Introduction

The Sierpiński Triangle is a fascinating fractal that has captured the imagination of mathematicians and computer scientists for decades. In this article, the author explores a simple bit-twiddling hack that produces the Sierpiński triangle using the C programming language. The hack involves iterating over a pair of integer coordinates and coloring each cell based on whether the bitwise AND of the coordinates is zero or non-zero. The author explains that the magic of the algorithm is not in the bitwise AND operation, but in the positional numeral system. They visualize the process of counting from 0 to 63 in binary and explain how the value of the least significant bit toggles with every tick, the next bit flips back and forth at half the frequency, and so on. The algorithm is an iterative block-removal approach in disguise, with the passes "parallelized" by the arithmetic logic unit of a CPU. The author concludes by explaining that the hack is a simple and elegant way to produce the Sierpiński triangle, and that the magic is in the positional numeral system. This article is a must-read for anyone interested in fractals, programming, and the power of the positional numeral system.
